sections.title: Retirement Accounts at a Glance
sections.content: A 401(k) is an employer-sponsored plan that allows pre-tax or Roth contributions through payroll deductions. Individual Retirement Accounts (IRAs) are personal accounts you can open at a financial institution. Both accounts help your money grow tax-advantaged, but they follow different contribution rules and offer different investment menus.

points.title: Contribution Limits
points.description: For 2025, employees can contribute up to $23,000 to a 401(k) plus a $7,500 catch-up if age 50+. IRAs allow $7,000 with a $1,000 catch-up.

points.title: Employer Match
points.description: Many employers match 3%-6% of pay. Contribute at least enough to capture the full matchâ€”it is an immediate 100% return.

points.title: Investment Menu
points.description: 401(k)s typically offer curated mutual funds. IRAs often provide a wider range of ETFs and stocks for more customization.

sections.title: Traditional vs Roth
sections.content: Traditional contributions reduce taxable income now but are taxed when withdrawn. Roth contributions are made with after-tax dollars yet deliver tax-free withdrawals in retirement.

sections.title: Decision Checklist
sections.content: Use a 401(k) up to the match first, then fund an IRA for investment flexibility. If you expect higher taxes later, consider Roth options. Verify plan fees and adjust investment selections once per year to stay aligned with your risk tolerance.

sections.title: Optimize Your Accounts
steps: Log into your 401(k) portal and confirm your contribution rate hits the full employer match.
Open or review an IRA at your preferred brokerage and evaluate contribution room for this year.
Compare traditional versus Roth contributions using your current and expected retirement tax brackets.
List the investment funds available in each account and categorize them as core (broad market) or specialty.
